data.text:
Spiders arenâ€™t everyoneâ€™s cup of tea, but jumping spiders have become an unlikely mascot for terrarium Tiktok of late, and Iâ€™m all for it.

With their tiny fuzzy bodies and (disproportionately) large goo-goo eyes, theyâ€™re undeniably cute. Though, maybe itâ€™s their mannerisms and personality that makes them such interesting pets?

Docile, curious, and friendly â€“ never words I thought Iâ€™d use about a spider, but thatâ€™s what Iâ€™m toldâ€¦

In this article, weâ€™re going to discuss the rise of jumping spider pets and their suitability in terrariums. Along with how to create the ideal terrarium setup for them should you be ready to make the leap.

Letâ€™s jump to it!

Terrarium Tribe is reader-supported. When you purchase through links on our site, we may earn an affiliate commission (at no further cost to you). ğŸ’œ

Why Get a Jumping Spider Pet?

Letâ€™s be honest; there have to be some good reasons for keeping jumping spider pets.

How else could so many people overcome their fear of spiders through 30-second videos? They must have some uniquely attractive qualities that other spiders donâ€™t â€“ and thatâ€™s certainly the case.

After seeing Aerith (Ben Newellâ€™s little jumping spider pet on TikTok) I knew I had to explore this trend further. Partly because sheâ€™s cute, partly because thatâ€™s a clear bridge to the terrarium world, and partly because Iâ€™m a huge Final Fantasy fanâ€¦

Fawning over spiders and video games aside, the terrarium setup that Ben prepared was fairly simple, too, so I can definitely see the appeal at first glance.

Letâ€™s take a closer look.

Fun personalities â€“ This is the big one, for sure. Jumping spiders really do have a typical petâ€™s personality, and theyâ€™re incredibly disarming. Not quite in the same way as a dog or a cat, but they are curious and surprisingly expressive.

Easy care â€“ They donâ€™t tend to have particularly complex care requirements as far as environment or feeding goes. They also donâ€™t spin webs, so maintenance isnâ€™t much of an issue either.

Low risk â€“ Sure, they do have fangs, and Iâ€™m sure it stings if it happens. However, according to WebMD, jumping spiders are harmless to humans. Which is good because they seem to like being handled.

Cool factor â€“ Ever seen a tiny spider leap dramatically across an enclosure to tackle its prey? Well, nowâ€™s your chance. These are the acrobatic daredevils of the spider world and theyâ€™re fascinating to watch.

As for cons, there arenâ€™t any that I can think of, except for the fact they donâ€™t live particularly long. You can expect them to live for up to a few years, so theyâ€™re low commitment in that sense.

Jumping Spider Terrarium Setup

Enclosure

Jumping spiders really are tiny, so they donâ€™t need a vast terrarium setup for them to get lost in.

But they are very active creatures. So â€“ relative to their size â€“ they still need plenty of space to explore and hunt in. Youâ€™d be feeding them small flying insects, so thereâ€™s a certain degree of leaping to be had.

Plus, we need to remember that they are natural climbers.

So, opting for a taller setup is definitely a good idea.

As Serpa discovered in his jumping spider video, these spiders make their nests at the top of their enclosure. So front-opening containers are best (unless you like to be a regular homewrecker).

A vented acrylic enclosure like these two options would be absolutely perfect,

This nifty Invertebrate Enclosure on Etsy.

Or, this Zilla Micro Enclosure on Amazon.

That said, thereâ€™s nothing to stop you from drilling some holes into any other appropriately sized/shaped container. Holes on the sides are best for cross-airflow.

Setup

Jumping spiders donâ€™t appear to need a complex setup.

As I understand it, theyâ€™ll need bright (indirect) light so that they can hunt through the day. If you donâ€™t have an appropriate spot in your home, a simple artificial lighting setup around/above the enclosure can help make sure you meet your spiderâ€™s needs.

Ideal temperature and humidity can vary according to species, so thatâ€™s for you to determine.

Hardscape is a must for all setups, though â€“ in one form or another.

People enjoy adding all manner of weird and wonderful objects to their enclosure (just look at this cute little cat run come doll house!), but I still prefer the natural look, so Iâ€™d recommend some driftwood branches.

You can choose a type that fits your container size (e.g., Spiderwood for smaller spaces, Mopani Wood for larger, and Cork Bark for any size).

It serves a dual function in both elevating the visual experience and giving your spider something to climb.

On the substrate front, honestly, most sterile terrarium mixes (i.e., no fertilizers or natural insecticides) would be fine â€“ whatever suits your plant choice.

Plants

Plants are probably the trickiest part of this terrarium setup for two main reasons.

The ventilation holes in your container will make it hard to maintain super-high humidity levels. So, youâ€™ll want to avoid plants that are particularly sensitive to humidity.

Most of the care advice Iâ€™ve seen recommends misting your container down very lightly and infrequently so that puts high moisture plants off the cards, e.g., water-hungry ferns.

Lots of people seem to opt for fake plants, but my honor as a terrarium maker will not allow it.

Real planted terrariums just look better, right? Itâ€™ll give them more of a sense of their natural habitat, and it gives them plenty of places to hide and chill.

For me, Iâ€™d keep it simple with some drought-tolerant small foliage plants (e.g., Peperomia â€˜Piccolo Bandaâ€™). But Iâ€™m told they prefer broad-leafed plants, so that should narrow things down.

Common Species of Pet Jumping Spider

Jumping spider species number in the thousands, so you might come across all manner of spiders in the wild. Honestly, Itâ€™s surprising how many keepers seem to catch their own pets in this space.

Itâ€™s something of a taboo practice in the reptile industry, but spiders are different, I guess.

All that said, there are two clear species that dominate the pet jumping spider market.

Bold Jumping Spider (Phidippus audax) â€“ Surprisingly named for their bold personalities rather than their bold, iridescent facial features. Works both ways, really.

Regal Jumping Spider (Phidippus regius) â€“ The bigger species, both in size and popularity as pets. theyâ€™re a tropical species, so they could be a better fit for the classic tropical terrarium.

Heavy Jumping Spider (Hyllus diardi) â€“ The largest of the jumping spider species, these are a perfect fit for humid, planted bioactive enclosures.

Thatâ€™s a Wrap, Spider-Style

Jumping spiders are the real deal and a genuinely cool pet.

If youâ€™re happy to stretch the definition of â€œterrarium,â€ then theyâ€™re a good fit. But if youâ€™re looking to add a new critter to your prize tropical tank, then it might not be the easiest fit.

Do you keep jumping spiders as pets in your terrarium?

Have you used real tropical plants? Iâ€™d love to hear how youâ€™ve done it. Let me know which plants youâ€™ve used in the comments below!
